title: Broadway Grosses Analysis
text:
— A view from financial prospective about the Broadway.
The dataset is sourced from Playbill and encompasses weekly box office grosses from 1985 to 2020, including financial figures for shows and theaters that are members of The Broadway League, the trade association for the Broadway theatre industry. This data provides a comprehensive overview of the commercial successes and trends within the theater industry. It is available for public access on the tidytuesday GitHub repository.

title: Broadway Grosses Analysis
section: Longevity and Success: Total Historical Grosses vs. Years of Run
text:
Longevity and Success: Total Historical Grosses vs. Years of Run The plot illustrates the relationship between the duration of a Broadway show’s run and its total historical grosses. While longer-running shows generally accumulate higher grosses, there are exceptions, indicating that other factors like popularity, ticket prices, and marketing also impact a show’s financial success. This underscores the multifaceted nature of the Broadway industry, where longevity is one of many contributors to a show’s financial performance. Code p <- plot_ly( data = tot_show, x = ~Year_Of_Run, y = ~Total_Gross, type = 'scatter', mode = 'markers', color = ~Show, # Color by Show text = ~paste("Show:", Show, "
Historical Total Gross:", Total_Gross, "
Year of Run:", Year_Of_Run), # Text to display on hover hoverinfo = "text" ) %>% layout( title = "Longevity and Success: Total Historical Grosses vs. Years of Run", xaxis = list(title = "Year of Run"), yaxis = list(title = "Historical Total Gross"), showlegend = FALSE ) p

title: Broadway Grosses Analysis
text:
Shows Ranked By Grosses


Code
#| warning: false
#| message: false

tot_show1<- tot_show%>%
  select(Show,Total_Gross,Average_Ticket_Price, Total_Seats_Sold,Rank,Year_Of_Run)

datatable(tot_show1)%>% 
  formatStyle(columns = names(tot_show1), fontSize = '70%')









Code
grosses1<- grosses_clean%>% select(week_ending,weekly_gross_overall,avg_ticket_price,seats_sold )

grosses1$week_ending <- as.Date(grosses1$week_ending)

# Extract the year from week_ending
grosses1$year <- format(grosses1$week_ending, "%Y")
summary_by_year <- grosses1 %>%
  group_by(year) %>%
  summarise(total_grosses = sum(weekly_gross_overall, na.rm = TRUE)/ 10^9,
            avg_ticket_price = mean(avg_ticket_price, na.rm = TRUE),
            total_seats_sold = sum(seats_sold, na.rm = TRUE)/ 10^6 )
summary_by_year<- summary_by_year %>%
  filter(year != 1985 & year != 2020)




summary_by_year$year <- as.numeric(summary_by_year$year)

plot <- plot_ly(data = summary_by_year, x = ~year) %>%
  add_trace(y = ~avg_ticket_price, name = 'Average Ticket Price', mode = 'lines', line = list(color = 'red')) %>%
  add_trace(y = ~total_seats_sold, name = 'Total Seats Sold', mode = 'lines', line = list(color = 'blue')) %>%
  add_trace(y = ~total_grosses, name = 'Total Grosses', mode = 'lines', line = list(color = 'green')) %>%
  layout(title = "Yearly Summary",
         xaxis = list(title = "Year"),
         yaxis = list(title = "Value"))

plot








Code
# Compute the correlation matrix
cor_matrix <- cor(tot_show[c("Total_Gross", "Average_Ticket_Price", "Total_Seats_Sold", "Week_Of_Run")], use = "complete.obs")

cor_matrix


                     Total_Gross Average_Ticket_Price Total_Seats_Sold
Total_Gross            1.0000000            0.2487810        0.9381962
Average_Ticket_Price   0.2487810            1.0000000        0.1457148
Total_Seats_Sold       0.9381962            0.1457148        1.0000000
Week_Of_Run            0.8656811            0.1319126        0.9483686
                     Week_Of_Run
Total_Gross            0.8656811
Average_Ticket_Price   0.1319126
Total_Seats_Sold       0.9483686
Week_Of_Run            1.0000000




Code
model <- lm(Total_Gross ~ Average_Ticket_Price + Total_Seats_Sold + Week_Of_Run, data = tot_show)
summary(model)



Call:
lm(formula = Total_Gross ~ Average_Ticket_Price + Total_Seats_Sold + 
    Week_Of_Run, data = tot_show)

Residuals:
       Min         1Q     Median         3Q        Max 
-294094850   -5288890     184567    6059478  393715501 

Coefficients:
                       Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)    
(Intercept)          -1.716e+07  1.787e+06  -9.604  < 2e-16 ***
Average_Ticket_Price  3.196e+05  2.729e+04  11.709  < 2e-16 ***
Total_Seats_Sold      9.625e+01  2.542e+00  37.859  < 2e-16 ***
Week_Of_Run          -2.075e+05  2.690e+04  -7.715 2.68e-14 ***
---

  (4 observations deleted due to missingness)

title: About
text:
About this blog
Hello! I’m Oskar, a data enthusiast and studing Master of Business Analytics In Monash University.
This is my blog where I share insights and analyses on interesting topics.
Feel free to explore and share your thoughts!

title: Broadway Grosses Analysis
text:
Trend Analysis


Code
grosses1 <- grosses%>% select(week_ending, weekly_gross_overall, avg_ticket_price,seats_sold)
grosses1$year <- as.integer(format(grosses$week_ending, "%Y"))

summary_by_year<- grosses1 %>%
  group_by(year) %>%
  mutate(Seats_Sold = sum(seats_sold, na.rm = TRUE)/10^5)%>%
  mutate(Average_Ticket_Price = mean(avg_ticket_price, na.rm = TRUE))%>%
  select(week_ending, weekly_gross_overall, Average_Ticket_Price,Seats_Sold,year)%>%
  distinct(week_ending, .keep_all = TRUE)%>%
  mutate(Yearly_Grosses = sum(weekly_gross_overall, na.rm = TRUE)/10^7) %>%
  ungroup()%>%
  select( Yearly_Grosses, Average_Ticket_Price,Seats_Sold,year)%>%
  distinct(year, .keep_all = TRUE)%>%
  filter(year != 1985 & year != 2020)



summary_by_year$year <- as.numeric(summary_by_year$year)

plot <- plot_ly(data = summary_by_year, x = ~year) %>%
  add_trace(y = ~Average_Ticket_Price, name = 'Average Ticket Price', mode = 'lines', line = list(color = 'red')) %>%
  add_trace(y = ~Seats_Sold, name = ' Seats Sold', mode = 'lines', line = list(color = 'blue')) %>%
  add_trace(y = ~Yearly_Grosses, name = 'Yearly Grosses', mode = 'lines', line = list(color = 'green')) %>%
  layout(title = "Yearly Summary",
         xaxis = list(title = "Year"),
         yaxis = list(title = "Value"))

plot







1. The trends of ticket prices and gross revenues exhibit similar slopes, while the trend for seats sold is comparatively less steep.


2. Seats sold displays noticeable fluctuations, whereas gross revenues and ticket prices trends are more stable, with ticket prices being the most stable.


3. From 1986 to 2006, the trends of gross revenues and seats sold were closely aligned. However, post-2006, gross revenues trend exhibited a stronger correlation with ticket prices.


Code
model <- lm(Total_Gross ~ Average_Ticket_Price + Total_Seats_Sold, data = tot_show)
summary(model)



Call:
lm(formula = Total_Gross ~ Average_Ticket_Price + Total_Seats_Sold, 
    data = tot_show)

Residuals:
       Min         1Q     Median         3Q        Max 
-270568372   -5271555     219771    6138038  445215115 

Coefficients:
                       Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)    
(Intercept)          -1.966e+07  1.803e+06  -10.90   <2e-16 ***
Average_Ticket_Price  3.238e+05  2.800e+04   11.57   <2e-16 ***
Total_Seats_Sold      7.767e+01  8.344e-01   93.08   <2e-16 ***
---
Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1

Residual standard error: 31210000 on 1115 degrees of freedom
  (4 observations deleted due to missingness)
Multiple R-squared:  0.893, Adjusted R-squared:  0.8929 
F-statistic:  4655 on 2 and 1115 DF,  p-value: < 2.2e-16




Code
summary_by_year1 <- summary_by_year 
summary_by_year1$Yearly_Grosses <- scale(summary_by_year1$Yearly_Grosses)
summary_by_year1$Average_Ticket_Price <- scale(summary_by_year1$Average_Ticket_Price)
summary_by_year1$Seats_Sold <- scale(summary_by_year1$Seats_Sold)

model1 <- lm(Yearly_Grosses ~ Average_Ticket_Price + Seats_Sold, data = summary_by_year1)
summary(model1)

  add_trace(y = ~Average_Ticket_Price, name = 'Average Ticket Price', mode = 'lines', line = list(color = 'red')) %>%
  add_trace(y = ~Seats_Sold, name = ' Seats Sold', mode = 'lines', line = list(color = 'blue')) %>%

title: Broadway Grosses Analysis
section: Unlocking the Dynamics of Broadway Grosses: The Power of Ticket Prices and Seat Sales”
text:
Unlocking the Dynamics of Broadway Grosses: The Power of Ticket Prices and Seat Sales”
The Broadway theater industry is a significant cultural and economic force, attracting millions of visitors and generating billions of dollars in revenue each year. Understanding the factors that drive its financial success is crucial. One way to gain insights into this industry is by analyzing historical trends in key variables such as gross revenues, ticket prices, and seats sold.
This analysis aims to provide a data-driven perspective on the financial dynamics of the Broadway theater industry. By examining historical trends, uncovering underlying patterns and building a predictive model, we aim to identify the most influential factors affecting Broadway gross revenues.
For those interested in exploring the data further, we have also developed a Shiny app, which can be accessed through the following link: Broadway Grosses Analysis shinyapp

title: Broadway Grosses Analysis
section: Tracking Trends: Gross Revenues, Ticket Prices, and Seats Sold Over Time
text:
Tracking Trends: Gross Revenues, Ticket Prices, and Seats Sold Over Time


Code
grosses <- readr::read_csv('https://raw.githubusercontent.com/rfordatascience/tidytuesday/master/data/2020/2020-04-28/grosses.csv', guess_max = 40000,show_col_types = FALSE)

grosses1 <- grosses%>% select(week_ending, weekly_gross_overall, avg_ticket_price,seats_sold)
grosses1$year <- as.integer(format(grosses$week_ending, "%Y"))

summary_by_year<- grosses1 %>%
  group_by(year) %>%
  mutate(Seats_Sold = sum(seats_sold, na.rm = TRUE)/10^5)%>%
  mutate(Average_Ticket_Price = mean(avg_ticket_price, na.rm = TRUE))%>%
  select(week_ending, weekly_gross_overall, Average_Ticket_Price,Seats_Sold,year)%>%
  distinct(week_ending, .keep_all = TRUE)%>%
  mutate(Yearly_Grosses = sum(weekly_gross_overall, na.rm = TRUE)/10^7) %>%
  ungroup()%>%
  select( Yearly_Grosses, Average_Ticket_Price,Seats_Sold,year)%>%
  distinct(year, .keep_all = TRUE)%>%
  filter(year != 1985 & year != 2020)

summary_by_year$year <- as.numeric(summary_by_year$year)

plot <- plot_ly(data = summary_by_year, x = ~year) %>%
  add_trace(y = ~Average_Ticket_Price, name = 'Average Ticket Price ($)', mode = 'lines', 
  line =      list(color = 'orange')) %>%
  add_trace(y = ~Seats_Sold, name = 'Seats Sold (100K)', mode = 'lines', line = list(color = 'navy'))   %>%
  add_trace(y = ~Yearly_Grosses, name = 'Yearly Grosses ($10M)', mode = 'lines', line = list(
  color = 'red')) %>%
  layout(title = "Analyzing Trends: Broadway's Revenues, Ticket Prices, and Seats Sold",
         xaxis = list(title = "Year", 
                      tickvals = seq(min(summary_by_year$year), 2019, by = 2),
                      tickangle = 45, 
                      showgrid = TRUE),
         yaxis = list(title = "Value"))

plot





Figure 1: Analyzing Trends: Broadway’s Revenues, Ticket Prices, and Seats Sold



As we can see from figure Figure 1,

Ticket prices and gross revenues appear to be intrinsically linked, moving in a similar slopes. However, the trajectory of seats sold follows a comparatively less steep. This observation suggests that revenue sensitivities are more closely tied to ticket pricing than to fluctuations in audience size.
Seats sold displays noticeable fluctuations, whereas gross revenues and ticket prices trends are more stable. Such observations hint at other dynamics influencing seat sales without significantly destabilizing gross revenues. It also indicates that ticket prices and gross revenues are less volatile and more predictable. A crucial takeaway here is the resilience and influence of ticket prices on sustaining revenues, even in the face of fluctuating seat sales.
From 1986 to 2006, the trends of gross revenues and seats sold were closely aligned. However, this alignment seems to pivot post-2006, with gross revenues becoming more closely associated with ticket prices. Such evolution suggest potential shifts in market dynamics, audience behaviors, or even strategic pricing adaptations.
From 1986 to 2019, gross revenues surged by 821%, ticket prices climbed by 325%, and seats sold rose by 120%. The narrative here underscores the paramount role of ticket pricing in driving the substantial surge in revenues

In conclusion, both the number of seats sold and ticket prices impact gross revenues. However, ticket prices have been a more influential factor, especially post-2006. The analysis highlights the importance of ticket pricing strategy in maximizing gross revenues.

title: Broadway Grosses Analysis
section: Predictive Power of Ticket Prices and Seats Sold on Yearly Grosses: A Regression Analysis”
text:
Predictive Power of Ticket Prices and Seats Sold on Yearly Grosses: A Regression Analysis”
The regression analysis aims to understand the relationship between yearly gross revenues and two independent variables: average ticket price and seats sold. To ensure comparability and to remove the scale effect, the variables were standardized before running the regression.


Code
summary_by_year1 <- summary_by_year 
summary_by_year1$Yearly_Grosses <- scale(summary_by_year1$Yearly_Grosses)
summary_by_year1$Average_Ticket_Price <- scale(summary_by_year1$Average_Ticket_Price)
summary_by_year1$Seats_Sold <- scale(summary_by_year1$Seats_Sold)

model1 <- lm(Yearly_Grosses ~ Average_Ticket_Price + Seats_Sold, data = summary_by_year1)
model1_summary <- summary(model1)
coef_df <- as.data.frame(coef(model1_summary))

model1_summary$table <- coef(model1_summary)
kable(model1_summary$table, align = 'c') %>%
  kable_styling(latex_options = c("striped", "scale_down"))




Table 1:  Regression Model Summary. 
 
  
      
    Estimate 
    Std. Error 
    t value 
    Pr(>|t|) 
  
 

  
    (Intercept) 
    0.0000000 
    0.0156150 
    0.00000 
    1.0000000 
  
  
    Average_Ticket_Price 
    0.8799148 
    0.0339823 
    25.89331 
    0.0000000 
  
  
    Seats_Sold 
    0.1292803 
    0.0339823 
    3.80434 
    0.0006273 
  






As we can see from table Table 1, the regression analysis indicates that both the average ticket price and the number of seats sold are significant predictors of yearly grosses. However, the average ticket price has a much larger coefficient (0.8799) compared to seats sold (0.1293), indicating that the average ticket price is a more important predictor of yearly grosses than the number of seats sold. This means that while both factors are important, strategies that focus on ticket pricing may have a larger impact on increasing yearly gross revenues of the Broadway than strategies focusing on increasing the number of seats sold.

title: Broadway Grosses Analysis
section: Cracking the Broadway Revenue Code: How Ticket Prices and Seat Sales Shape the Game
text:
Cracking the Broadway Revenue Code: How Ticket Prices and Seat Sales Shape the Game
Broadway isn’t just about the glitz, glamour, and those thrilling stage performances. It’s also a massive economic machine, raking in big bucks every year. But ever wondered what makes some shows sell like hotcakes? Let’s delve into the fascinating world of Broadway’s financial landscape, examining how ticket prices and seat sales have shaped its revenues over the years.
For those interested in exploring the data further, we have also developed a Shiny app, which can be accessed through the following link: Broadway Grosses Analysis shinyapp

1. Tracking Trends: Gross Revenues, Ticket Prices, and Seats Sold Over Time


Code
grosses <- readr::read_csv('https://raw.githubusercontent.com/rfordatascience/tidytuesday/master/data/2020/2020-04-28/grosses.csv', guess_max = 40000,show_col_types = FALSE)

grosses1 <- grosses%>% select(week_ending, weekly_gross_overall, avg_ticket_price,seats_sold)
grosses1$year <- as.integer(format(grosses$week_ending, "%Y"))

summary_by_year<- grosses1 %>%
  group_by(year) %>%
  mutate(Seats_Sold = sum(seats_sold, na.rm = TRUE)/10^5)%>%
  mutate(Average_Ticket_Price = mean(avg_ticket_price, na.rm = TRUE))%>%
  select(week_ending, weekly_gross_overall, Average_Ticket_Price,Seats_Sold,year)%>%
  distinct(week_ending, .keep_all = TRUE)%>%
  mutate(Yearly_Grosses = sum(weekly_gross_overall, na.rm = TRUE)/10^7) %>%
  ungroup()%>%
  select( Yearly_Grosses, Average_Ticket_Price,Seats_Sold,year)%>%
  distinct(year, .keep_all = TRUE)%>%
  filter(year != 1985 & year != 2020)

summary_by_year$year <- as.numeric(summary_by_year$year)

plot <- plot_ly(data = summary_by_year, x = ~year) %>%
  add_trace(y = ~Average_Ticket_Price, name = 'Average Ticket Price ($)', mode = 'lines', 
  line =      list(color = 'orange')) %>%
  add_trace(y = ~Seats_Sold, name = 'Seats Sold (100K)', mode = 'lines', line = list(color = 'navy'))   %>%
  add_trace(y = ~Yearly_Grosses, name = 'Yearly Grosses ($10M)', mode = 'lines', line = list(
  color = 'red')) %>%
  layout(title = "Analyzing Trends: Broadway's Revenues, Ticket Prices, and Seats Sold",
         xaxis = list(title = "Year", 
                      tickvals = seq(min(summary_by_year$year), 2019, by = 2),
                      tickangle = 45, 
                      showgrid = TRUE),
         yaxis = list(title = "Value"))

plot





Figure 1: Analyzing Trends: Broadway’s Revenues, Ticket Prices, and Seats Sold



As we can see from figure Figure 1:

Ticket prices and gross revenues appear to be intrinsically linked, moving in a similar slopes. However, the trajectory of seats sold follows a comparatively less steep. This observation suggests that revenue sensitivities are more closely tied to ticket pricing than to fluctuations in audience size.
Seats sold displays noticeable fluctuations, whereas gross revenues and ticket prices trends are more stable. Such observations hint at other dynamics influencing seat sales without significantly destabilizing gross revenues. It also indicates that ticket prices and gross revenues are less volatile and more predictable. A crucial takeaway here is the resilience and influence of ticket prices on sustaining revenues, even in the face of fluctuating seat sales.
From 1986 to 2006, the trends of gross revenues and seats sold were closely aligned. However, this alignment seems to pivot post-2006, with gross revenues becoming more closely associated with ticket prices. Such evolution suggest potential shifts in market dynamics, audience behaviors, or even strategic pricing adaptations.
From 1986 to 2019, gross revenues surged by 821%, ticket prices climbed by 325%, and seats sold rose by 120%. The narrative here underscores the paramount role of ticket pricing in driving the substantial surge in revenues

In conclusion, both the number of seats sold and ticket prices impact gross revenues. However, ticket prices have been a more influential factor, especially post-2006. The analysis highlights the importance of ticket pricing strategy in maximizing gross revenues.


2. Influence of Ticket Prices and Seats Sold on Annual Grosses: A Regression Analysis”
Our journey now transitions to a more analytical phase, focusing on regression analysis. It aims to understand the relationship between yearly gross revenues and two independent variables: average ticket price and seats sold. To ensure comparability and to remove the scale effect, the variables were standardized before running the regression.


Code
summary_by_year1 <- summary_by_year 
summary_by_year1$Yearly_Grosses <- scale(summary_by_year1$Yearly_Grosses)
summary_by_year1$Average_Ticket_Price <- scale(summary_by_year1$Average_Ticket_Price)
summary_by_year1$Seats_Sold <- scale(summary_by_year1$Seats_Sold)

model1 <- lm(Yearly_Grosses ~ Average_Ticket_Price + Seats_Sold, data = summary_by_year1)
model1_summary <- summary(model1)
coef_df <- as.data.frame(coef(model1_summary))

model1_summary$table <- coef(model1_summary)
kable(model1_summary$table, align = 'c') %>%
  kable_styling(latex_options = c("striped", "scale_down"))




Table 1:  Regression Model Summary. 
 
  
      
    Estimate 
    Std. Error 
    t value 
    Pr(>|t|) 
  
 

  
    (Intercept) 
    0.0000000 
    0.0156150 
    0.00000 
    1.0000000 
  
  
    Average_Ticket_Price 
    0.8799148 
    0.0339823 
    25.89331 
    0.0000000 
  
  
    Seats_Sold 
    0.1292803 
    0.0339823 
    3.80434 
    0.0006273 
  






Directing attention to table Table 1, the regression outputs present a clear picture. Both ticket prices and seats sold emerge as significant contributors to yearly grosses. However, the average ticket price has a much larger coefficient (0.8799) compared to seats sold (0.1293), indicating that the average ticket price is a more important predictor of yearly grosses than the number of seats sold. This means that while both factors are important, strategies that focus on ticket pricing may have a larger impact on increasing yearly gross revenues of the Broadway than strategies focusing on increasing the number of seats sold.


3. Beyond the Spotlight: Uncovering Broadway’s Next Big Questions
To really get a full picture of Broadway’s financial dance, we should consider a few more angles in our next deep dives. Let’s think about the big events or trends outside of Broadway that could be influencing ticket sales and prices. It’d also be fun to zoom in on specific shows – what made some soar while others stumbled? And lastly, let’s not forget about us, the audience. What makes us tick, choose a show, or even splurge on a pricier seat? These are exciting avenues to explore in upcoming posts. Stay tuned!

title: Broadway Grosses Analysis
section: Influence of Ticket Prices and Seats Sold on Annual Grosses: A Regression Analysis”
text:
Influence of Ticket Prices and Seats Sold on Annual Grosses: A Regression Analysis”
Our journey now transitions to a more analytical phase, focusing on regression analyses. The regression analysis aims to understand the relationship between yearly gross revenues and two independent variables: average ticket price and seats sold. To ensure comparability and to remove the scale effect, the variables were standardized before running the regression.


Code
summary_by_year1 <- summary_by_year 
summary_by_year1$Yearly_Grosses <- scale(summary_by_year1$Yearly_Grosses)
summary_by_year1$Average_Ticket_Price <- scale(summary_by_year1$Average_Ticket_Price)
summary_by_year1$Seats_Sold <- scale(summary_by_year1$Seats_Sold)

model1 <- lm(Yearly_Grosses ~ Average_Ticket_Price + Seats_Sold, data = summary_by_year1)
model1_summary <- summary(model1)
coef_df <- as.data.frame(coef(model1_summary))

model1_summary$table <- coef(model1_summary)

    3.80434 
    0.0006273 
  






Directing attention to table Table 1, the regression outputs present a clear picture. Both ticket prices and seats sold emerge as significant contributors to yearly grosses. However, the average ticket price has a much larger coefficient (0.8799) compared to seats sold (0.1293), indicating that the average ticket price is a more important predictor of yearly grosses than the number of seats sold. This means that while both factors are important, strategies that focus on ticket pricing may have a larger impact on increasing yearly gross revenues of the Broadway than strategies focusing on increasing the number of seats sold.

title: Broadway Grosses Analysis
section: Beyond the Spotlight: Uncovering Broadway’s Next Big Questions
text:
Beyond the Spotlight: Uncovering Broadway’s Next Big Questions
To really get a full picture of Broadway’s financial dance, we should consider a few more angles in our next deep dives. Let’s think about the big events or trends outside of Broadway that could be influencing ticket sales and prices. It’d also be fun to zoom in on specific shows – what made some soar while others stumbled? And lastly, let’s not forget about us, the audience. What makes us tick, choose a show, or even splurge on a pricier seat? These are exciting avenues to explore in upcoming posts. Stay tuned!
